guide.introduction: Here are 3 simple paper-crafting techniques you can combine and recombine to create gorgeous holiday cards. I’ve used machine sewing, heat embossing, and paper embroidery to make 2 very different sets of greetings. What other variations can you come up with?
guide.introduction_rendered:
Here are 3 simple paper-crafting techniques you can combine and recombine to create gorgeous holiday cards. I’ve used machine sewing, heat embossing, and paper embroidery to make 2 very different sets of greetings. What other variations can you come up with?

Relevant parts
  • Blank cards
  • Decorative scrapbook paper
  • Adhesive photo corners
  • Thread
  • Embossing ink
  • Embossing powder
  • Pearl cotton embroidery floss
Tools
  • Crewel needle
  • Glue stick
  • Hand-sewing needle
  • Heat gun
  • Long quilting pin
  • Masking tape
  • Padded surface such as a cork trivet or folded felt
  • Rubber stamp of your choice
  • Scissors
  • Sewing machine
  • Soft paintbrush

parts.notes: for sewing - I used variegated polyester thread and metallic thread; you can also use all-purpose thread.
for heat embossing - Powder and ink are sold in scrapbooking stores, or at rangerink.com.

lines.text: Adjust your machine.
lines.text_raw: Adjust your machine.

lines.text: When you use your sewing machine to sew on paper, it’s a good idea to switch to a heavy-duty needle and a teflon presser foot, if available. You may also need to loosen the tension a bit — make a few rows of stitches on a test card to see if this is the case.
lines.text_raw: When you use your sewing machine to sew on paper, it’s a good idea to switch to a heavy-duty needle and a teflon presser foot, if available. You may also need to loosen the tension a bit — make a few rows of stitches on a test card to see if this is the case.

lines.text: Use your test card to sew a practice row before you work on an actual card. Some decorative stitches will need further tension adjustments, and you’ll want to know this before you start stitching on your handmade cards.
lines.text_raw: Use your test card to sew a practice row before you work on an actual card. Some decorative stitches will need further tension adjustments, and you’ll want to know this before you start stitching on your handmade cards.

lines.text: At the end of a seam, take the loose end of the thread on the front of the card and thread it onto a hand-sewing needle. Then sew it through to the back of the card, and tie the 2 ends in a double knot. Clip off the excess thread.
lines.text_raw: At the end of a seam, take the loose end of the thread on the front of the card and thread it onto a hand-sewing needle. Then sew it through to the back of the card, and tie the 2 ends in a double knot. Clip off the excess thread.

lines.text: Ink up and stamp.
lines.text_raw: Ink up and stamp.

lines.text: Generously ink up a rubber stamp with embossing ink. This ink is often clear, so look for its sheen on the stamp to make sure you have enough coverage.
lines.text_raw: Generously ink up a rubber stamp with embossing ink. This ink is often clear, so look for its sheen on the stamp to make sure you have enough coverage.

lines.text: Then press the inked stamp firmly onto the greeting card.
lines.text_raw: Then press the inked stamp firmly onto the greeting card.

lines.text: Use a soft paintbrush to pick up the embossing powder from its container.
lines.text_raw: Use a soft paintbrush to pick up the embossing powder from its container.

lines.text: Hold the brush over the stamped design and tap it to scatter the powder.
lines.text_raw: Hold the brush over the stamped design and tap it to scatter the powder.

lines.text: Repeat this process until the stamped design has  a generous coating of embossing powder.
lines.text_raw: Repeat this process until the stamped design has  a generous coating of embossing powder.

lines.text: Then tap the card over a wastebasket to remove any excess powder.
lines.text_raw: Then tap the card over a wastebasket to remove any excess powder.

lines.text: Turn on the heat gun and hold it over the embossing powder, moving it constantly. After a few seconds, the powder will begin to melt and turn shiny.
lines.text_raw: Turn on the heat gun and hold it over the embossing powder, moving it constantly. After a few seconds, the powder will begin to melt and turn shiny.

lines.text: Continue heating until all the powder has melted, then allow the embossing to cool before handling.
lines.text_raw: Continue heating until all the powder has melted, then allow the embossing to cool before handling.

lines.text: Plan and poke.
lines.text_raw: Plan and poke.

lines.text: Decide what design to embroider on your card.
lines.text_raw: Decide what design to embroider on your card.

lines.text: Open the card flat and place it on a padded surface.
lines.text_raw: Open the card flat and place it on a padded surface.

lines.text: Place  a pattern or sketch over the front of the card and use a quilting pin to poke the holes you’ll need for embroidery through the cardstock.
lines.text_raw: Place  a pattern or sketch over the front of the card and use a quilting pin to poke the holes you’ll need for embroidery through the cardstock.

lines.text: Instead of knotting the floss at the beginning and end of stitching, secure the ends with small pieces of masking tape. They’ll lay flat and keep the card from getting bulky.
lines.text_raw: Instead of knotting the floss at the beginning and end of stitching, secure the ends with small pieces of masking tape. They’ll lay flat and keep the card from getting bulky.

lines.text: Follow your pre-punched holes to embroider on the card.
lines.text_raw: Follow your pre-punched holes to embroider on the card.

lines.text: Find your image.
lines.text_raw: Find your image.

lines.text: You can find lots of vintage images online. Try  a group search on flickr.com for “vintage photographs.” But be sure to get the owner’s permission before using these images.
lines.text_raw: You can find lots of vintage images online. Try  a group search on flickr.com for “vintage photographs.” But be sure to get the owner’s permission before using these images.

lines.text: If you’re using your own old photographs for this project, I recommend that you scan them and print copies onto photographic paper instead of using originals.
lines.text_raw: If you’re using your own old photographs for this project, I recommend that you scan them and print copies onto photographic paper instead of using originals.

lines.text: Adhere the photo to the cardstock with a little glue stick before doing any sewing, stamping, or embroidery.
lines.text_raw: Adhere the photo to the cardstock with a little glue stick before doing any sewing, stamping, or embroidery.

lines.text: If you like, you can add some adhesive photo corners as well.
lines.text_raw: If you like, you can add some adhesive photo corners as well.

lines.text: Start collecting.
lines.text_raw: Start collecting.

lines.text: Save magazine subscription cards, postcards, and other cardstock junk mail.
lines.text_raw: Save magazine subscription cards, postcards, and other cardstock junk mail.

lines.text: Cut any silhouette you like — I’ve used an ornament motif here, but the possibilities are endless.
lines.text_raw: Cut any silhouette you like — I’ve used an ornament motif here, but the possibilities are endless.

lines.text: Adhere the cutouts to the card with a little glue stick before doing any sewing or embroidery.
lines.text_raw: Adhere the cutouts to the card with a little glue stick before doing any sewing or embroidery.

lines.text: If you want to heat-emboss the cutouts, do so before gluing them to the card.
lines.text_raw: If you want to heat-emboss the cutouts, do so before gluing them to the card.

lines.text: If you run machine stitching off the edge of the card, as I’ve done here, don’t worry about knotting the threads at the back of the card. Instead, just wrap both loose ends around to the back and secure them with a small piece of masking tape.
lines.text_raw: If you run machine stitching off the edge of the card, as I’ve done here, don’t worry about knotting the threads at the back of the card. Instead, just wrap both loose ends around to the back and secure them with a small piece of masking tape.

lines.text: Glue a coordinating piece of decorative paper to the inside front of the card, to cover up the back of your sewing and embroidery.
lines.text_raw: Glue a coordinating piece of decorative paper to the inside front of the card, to cover up the back of your sewing and embroidery.

lines.text: Write a quick message and you’re done!
lines.text_raw: Write a quick message and you’re done!
